questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a compressible swelling root of nose; most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Meningoencephalocele. A compressible swelling at the root of the nose in a 2-year-old child is most likely a meningoencephalocele, which is a congenital defect where herniation of meninges and brain tissue occurs through a skull defect (typically in the anterior cranial fossa). These lesions are often soft, non-pulsatile, and increase in size with crying or straining (positive Furstenberg sign) due to increased intracranial pressure. They may also be associated with nasal obstruction, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leakage, or other craniofacial anomalies. Incorrect Options: (A) A-V malformation – Incorrect: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are vascular anomalies that present as pulsatile swellings with an associated bruit or thrill due to abnormal connections between arteries and veins. They are not typically compressible and do not increase in size with crying or straining. (B) Lacrimal sac cyst – Incorrect: A lacrimal sac cyst (dacryocystocele) presents as a firm, non-compressible, bluish swelling below the medial canthus near the nasolacrimal duct. It does not typically occur at the root of the nose and is not affected by crying or straining. (C) Ethmoid sinus cyst – Incorrect: A cystic lesion arising from the ethmoid sinus is uncommon in infants and would typically present with localized swelling and possibly sinus-related symptoms, such as nasal congestion or discharge. It would not be compressible or fluctuate with crying.

choices.text: Admit to the medical floor for monitoring of progression of symptoms

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic bacterial sinusitis presents to the emergency department with a very severe headache. While waiting to be seen, he develops a generalized grand mal seizure. Physical examination, after the seizure is over, demonstrates high fever, exophthalmos, papilledema, and nerve palsies of the VI and III cranial nerves on one side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Emergency CT scan. The patient presents with a history of chronic bacterial sinusitis, severe headache, fever, exophthalmos, papilledema, and cranial nerve palsies (VI and III), followed by a generalized seizure, which strongly suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST). CST is a life-threatening condition caused by the spread of infection (typically from the sinuses, face, or orbit) to the cavernous sinus via venous drainage pathways, leading to thrombosis, increased intracranial pressure, and neurological deficits. Why Emergency CT Scan? An emergency contrast-enhanced CT or MRI is essential to confirm the diagnosis by identifying thrombosis, sinus expansion, or secondary complications like abscesses or infarcts. MRI with MR venography is the gold standard, but a CT scan is quicker and more readily available, making it the first-line imaging choice in an emergency. Incorrect Options: (A) Admit to the medical floor for monitoring of progression of symptoms – Incorrect: Given the severity of symptoms, including cranial nerve involvement and seizures, immediate imaging is required. Delaying diagnosis and treatment can be fatal. The patient should be evaluated urgently, and admission should follow imaging confirmation. (C) Emergency exploratory surgery – Incorrect: Surgery is not the first step in managing cavernous sinus thrombosis. The treatment primarily involves IV antibiotics, anticoagulation (controversial), and possibly steroids. Surgery may be needed only if there is a localized abscess or worsening orbital complications. (D) Emergency ultrasound – Incorrect: Ultrasound is not useful for diagnosing CST, as it cannot effectively visualize deep venous structures in the skull. Advanced imaging (CT/MRI) is required.

questions.text: Symptom not favouring the diagnosis of inverted papilloma :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Translucent bloodless mass. Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It typically arises from the lateral nasal wall and has a strong association with human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV-6 and HPV-11. One of its hallmark features is that it appears as a friable, vascular, polypoid mass, often exhibiting bleeding upon touch. Unlike benign nasal polyps, which are translucent and avascular, inverted papillomas are typically opaque and vascular. The presence of a translucent, bloodless mass is more indicative of a benign inflammatory polyp rather than an inverted papilloma. Incorrect Options: (A) Unilateral obstruction – Correct feature: Inverted papillomas usually cause unilateral nasal obstruction due to their asymmetric growth pattern. In contrast, inflammatory nasal polyps are more commonly bilateral. (B) Rhinorrhea – Correct feature: Patients with inverted papilloma may experience unilateral rhinorrhea, often due to associated mucosal irritation and obstruction of normal sinus drainage. (C) Diplopia – Correct feature: Advanced cases of inverted papilloma can extend into the orbit, leading to proptosis and diplopia due to orbital invasion or compression of the extraocular muscles.

questions.text: Most common site of ‘squamous cell carcinoma’ nasal cavity is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lateral wall. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the nasal cavity is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, often associated with risk factors like smoking, occupational exposure (wood dust, nickel, chromium), and HPV infection. The lateral wall of the nasal cavity is the most common site because it houses important structures like the middle and inferior turbinates and has a rich supply of respiratory epithelium, which is prone to malignant transformation. Incorrect Options: (A) Little’s area – Incorrect: Little’s area, located in the anterior nasal septum (Kiesselbach’s plexus), is the most common site for epistaxis but is not a common site for SCC. (B) Inferior turbinate – Incorrect: While SCC can occur on the inferior turbinate, it is less common than on the lateral wall, which has a larger surface area and is more prone to chronic irritation and carcinogenic exposure. (D) Middle meatus – Incorrect: The middle meatus is an important drainage pathway for the sinuses, but it is not the most common site for SCC. However, tumors of the lateral wall may extend into the middle meatus.

Correct Answer (B) Excision with cautery at base. Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic protist-like pathogen. It commonly affects the mucous membranes of the nose, nasopharynx, conjunctiva, and occasionally the skin and genital mucosa. The disease presents as a painless, friable, polypoidal mass with a strawberry-like appearance, often associated with recurrent epistaxis. The ideal treatment is complete surgical excision with wide margins, followed by cauterization of the base (usually with electrocautery or chemical agents like trichloroacetic acid) to reduce recurrence. Since rhinosporidiosis has a high recurrence rate, excision with cautery is necessary to ensure the removal of all spores. Incorrect Options: (A) Rifampicin – Incorrect: Rifampicin is an antibiotic primarily used for tuberculosis and leprosy. It has no proven efficacy in treating rhinosporidiosis, as Rhinosporidium seeberi is not a bacterial pathogen. (C) Dapsone – Incorrect: Dapsone has been studied as an adjunct therapy for rhinosporidiosis, as it may help reduce recurrence by inhibiting spore proliferation. However, it is not curative, and surgical excision remains the gold standard treatment. Dapsone is not effective as monotherapy. (D) Laser – Incorrect: While laser excision can be used in some cases, it is not the preferred treatment. Laser therapy does not completely eliminate spores, leading to a higher recurrence rate compared to traditional excision with cautery.

Correct Answer (B) Rhinoscleroma. Russell bodies are eosinophilic, immunoglobulin-filled inclusions found inside plasma cells. They are formed due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins within the endoplasmic reticulum of plasma cells, typically in chronic inflammatory conditions. In rhinoscleroma, a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, Russell bodies are commonly seen in Mikulicz cells, which are large histiocytes containing intracellular bacteria. The disease primarily affects the nasal cavity but can involve the pharynx, larynx, and trachea, leading to progressive nasal obstruction and deformity. Incorrect Options: (A) Rhinosporidiosis – Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents as a friable, polypoidal, strawberry-like mass. Histologically, it shows sporangia containing endospores, but Russell bodies are not a feature. (C) Mucormycosis – Mucormycosis (zygomycosis) is an invasive fungal infection that primarily affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., diabetics, post-transplant individuals). It shows broad, ribbon-like, aseptate fungal hyphae with tissue necrosis and angioinvasion, but Russell bodies are not a characteristic finding. (D) All – Since Russell bodies are specific to rhinoscleroma

questions.text: Which of the following sinus is not visible on Water’s View
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Posterior ethmoid. Water’s view (occipitomental view) is a radiographic projection primarily used to evaluate the paranasal sinuses. The X-ray beam is directed at an angle of 37° to 45° to the orbitomeatal line, providing a clear view of the maxillary sinuses while also visualizing the frontal and anterior ethmoid sinuses. However, the posterior ethmoid sinuses are not well-visualized in Water’s view because they are located deeper in the skull, near the sphenoid sinus. These sinuses are better assessed using lateral view or CT scan. Incorrect Options: (A) Maxillary sinus – Incorrect: The maxillary sinus is the most prominently visualized sinus on Water’s view because the X-ray beam passes directly through it. Any pathology like sinusitis, fractures, or tumors can be easily detected. (B) Sphenoid sinus – Incorrect: The sphenoid sinus is not well-visualized on Water’s view, but it may be faintly seen. A lateral view or CT scan is preferred for better visualization. (C) Frontal sinus – Incorrect: The frontal sinuses are visible in Water’s view, though they are not as clearly seen as the maxillary sinuses. Their visibility depends on the angle of the X-ray beam and individual sinus development.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates antrochoanal polyp from ethmoidal polyp?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Best seen on posterior rhinoscopy. An antrochoanal polyp (ACP) originates from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, often presenting as a single unilateral mass. It is best visualized on posterior rhinoscopy, where it appears as a smooth, pale mass in the nasopharynx, extending from the posterior nasal cavity. In contrast, ethmoidal polyps arise from the ethmoid sinuses, are typically bilateral and multiple, and are seen in conditions like nasal polyposis and allergic rhinitis. They do not extend into the choana and are best visualized on anterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy. Incorrect Options: (A) They are multiple Antrochoanal polyps are solitary, while ethmoidal polyps are multiple. This characteristic differentiates ethmoidal polyps but does not distinguish ACP specifically. (C) They are bilateral Ethmoidal polyps are typically bilateral, whereas antrochoanal polyps are unilateral. This is a distinguishing feature, but it does not directly explain how ACP is best diagnosed. (D) Recurrence on polypectomy Ethmoidal polyps have a higher recurrence rate due to underlying allergic or inflammatory conditions. Antrochoanal polyps have a lower recurrence rate if completely excised, including the antral portion.

questions.text: Inverted papilloma is characterized by all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Seen more often in females. Inverted papilloma (Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that arises from the Schneiderian (respiratory) epithelium lining the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It has a high potential for recurrence and a 10–15% risk of malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. This tumor is more common in males, typically between the 5th and 7th decades of life. The male-to-female ratio is approximately 3:1, making option (B) incorrect. Incorrect Options: (A) Also called Schneiderian papilloma Inverted papilloma arises from the Schneiderian epithelium, which is derived from ectoderm and lines the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It is also called Schneiderian papilloma due to this origin. (C) Presents with epistaxis and nasal obstruction Unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis are the most common presenting symptoms. The tumor may also cause facial pain or sinus involvement in advanced cases. (D) Originates from the lateral wall of the nose Inverted papilloma most commonly originates from the lateral nasal wall, particularly near the middle meatus. This helps differentiate it from nasal polyps, which commonly arise from the ethmoid sinuses.

questions.text: Study the figure and diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rhinophyma. Rhinophyma is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder that primarily affects the nose, causing thickening, fibrosis, and sebaceous gland hypertrophy. It is considered a severe form of rosacea, characterized by an enlarged, bulbous, and reddish nose with an irregular, nodular surface. This condition is more common in older males and is often associated with long-term untreated rosacea. Although it was historically linked to alcohol use, this is a misconception—rhinophyma occurs independently of alcohol consumption. Incorrect Options: (B) Rhinolith – Incorrect: A rhinolith is a calcareous concretion formed in the nasal cavity due to the deposition of salts around a foreign body. It presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and sometimes epistaxis, but does not cause nasal skin thickening as seen in rhinophyma. (C) Keratotic Papilloma – Incorrect: Keratotic papilloma is a rare benign lesion of the nasal cavity that presents as a small, firm, and verrucous growth. It is not associated with sebaceous gland hypertrophy or the bulbous nasal deformity characteristic of rhinophyma. (D) Inverted Papilloma – Incorrect: Inverted papilloma arises from the lateral nasal wall and typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. It does not cause external nasal deformity, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: Most common malignant tumour invading skin of nose is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rodent ulcer. Rodent ulcer is a term used for basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the skin, which is the most common malignant tumor that invades the skin of the nose. It is a slow-growing, locally invasive malignancy that rarely metastasizes but can cause extensive local tissue destruction if untreated. BCC typically presents as a painless, pearly, or ulcerated lesion with rolled edges and central necrosis. It most commonly affects the nose, eyelids, and other sun-exposed areas of the face. Chronic sun exposure, fair skin, and older age are major risk factors. Incorrect Options: (A) Rhinophyma Rhinophyma is a benign skin disorder associated with rosacea, leading to sebaceous gland hyperplasia and a bulbous nose. It does not invade surrounding tissues like a malignancy. (C) Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) SCC is the second most common skin cancer affecting the nose. While it is more aggressive than BCC, BCC (rodent ulcer) is still the most common tumor invading the nasal skin. (D) Melanoma Melanoma is a highly aggressive malignancy but is less common than BCC. It tends to metastasize early and usually presents as an irregular pigmented lesion rather than a slowly growing ulcer.

choices.text: Malignancy of infrastructure of maxillary sinus has poor prognosis
Woodworker carcinoma is adenocarcinoma of ethmoid
Ringertz tumour of nose is a premalignant condition
Esthesioneuroblastoma is a malignant tumour which originates from the olfactory neuroepithelium of nose.

questions.text: All of the following are true about nose and sinus malignancy except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignancy of infrastructure of maxillary sinus has poor prognosis. Malignancies of the maxillary sinus are classified based on their site of origin: Infrastructure – Involves the alveolar process, hard palate, and floor of the sinus. Suprastructure – Involves the orbital floor, ethmoid sinus, and nasal cavity. Tumors of the infrastructure tend to present earlier with symptoms like loose teeth, oral ulceration, and swelling, leading to earlier detection and a relatively better prognosis. In contrast, tumors of the suprastructure often remain silent until they invade the orbit or skull base, making their prognosis worse. Thus, option (A) is incorrect because suprastructure tumors, not infrastructure tumors, have a poorer prognosis. Incorrect Options: (B) Woodworker carcinoma is adenocarcinoma of ethmoid Woodworkers have an increased risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the ethmoid sinus, primarily due to prolonged exposure to wood dust. This occupational hazard is well-documented and recognized as a risk factor for sinonasal malignancies. (C) Ringertz tumor of nose is a premalignant condition Ringertz tumor refers to dysplasia or carcinoma in situ of the nasal epithelium, which is considered a premalignant condition. It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) if not treated early. (D) Esthesioneuroblastoma is a malignant tumor which originates from the olfactory neuroepithelium of the nose Esthesioneuroblastoma (olfactory neuroblastoma) is a rare but highly malignant tumor arising from the olfactory neuroepithelium in the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate. It often presents with nasal obstruction, anosmia, epistaxis, and sometimes intracranial extension.

questions.text: According to Lederman’s classification which of the followingis not included in suprastructure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Respiratory area of nose. According to Lederman’s classification, malignancies of the maxillary sinus are divided into two regions based on prognosis: Infrastructure – Includes the alveolar process, hard palate, and floor of the sinus. Suprastructure – Includes the ethmoid sinus, frontal sinus, olfactory area of the nose, and orbital floor. Tumors originating from the suprastructure tend to have a poorer prognosis due to their proximity to the orbit, skull base, and intracranial structures. The respiratory area of the nose, which consists of the inferior and middle turbinates and the floor of the nasal cavity, is not part of the suprastructure. It does not have the same aggressive tumor behavior as the suprastructure regions. Incorrect Options: (A) Ethmoid sinus The ethmoid sinus is located superior to the maxillary sinus and forms part of the suprastructure. Tumors here can extend into the orbit and skull base, leading to severe complications. (B) Frontal sinus The frontal sinus, positioned at the superior aspect of the nasal cavity, is also part of the suprastructure. Malignancies here often invade the anterior cranial fossa, making them more dangerous. (C) Olfactory area of nose The olfactory area (roof of the nasal cavity, near the cribriform plate) is included in the suprastructure because of its proximity to the skull base. Esthesioneuroblastoma, a rare but aggressive tumor, originates from this region.

questions.text: Coincidental malignancy in upper respiratory tract with inverted papilloma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4%. Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that arises from the Schneiderian epithelium of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It has a well-documented association with synchronous or metachronous malignancy, most commonly squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Studies have shown that approximately 4% of cases of inverted papilloma are associated with a coincidental malignancy in the upper respiratory tract, particularly in the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, or nasopharynx. The risk of malignant transformation increases with recurrence, incomplete excision, and HPV infection (especially HPV 16 and 18). Incorrect Options: (A) 2% The reported incidence of coincidental malignancy is higher than 2%, making this answer incorrect. (B) 5% While some studies suggest a range of 4-10%, the most widely accepted figure is 4%, making 5% an overestimate. (D) 0.1% The risk is significantly higher than 0.1%, as malignant transformation is a well-recognized complication of inverted papilloma.

questions.text: Friable, “strawberry” red (vascular) polypoid nasal lesion are feature of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rhinosporidiosis. Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic parasite-like organism. It primarily affects the nasal cavity, conjunctiva, and oropharynx. A characteristic feature of rhinosporidiosis is the presence of a "strawberry-like" vascular polypoid lesion. These lesions are: Bright red, soft, and friable, often bleeding on touch. Typically arise from the nasal mucosa, particularly the inferior turbinate and nasal septum. Associated with chronic nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and mucoid discharge. Incorrect Options: (A) Hypertrophic rhinitis Hypertrophic rhinitis results from chronic inflammation leading to thickened, edematous nasal mucosa. It does not form vascular, friable polyps but instead presents as diffuse mucosal thickening. (C) Rhinoscleroma Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, is a chronic granulomatous condition of the nasal mucosa. It presents with woody hard nodules and scarring rather than strawberry-red polypoid lesions. (D) Rhinitis caseosa Rhinitis caseosa is a rare chronic condition characterized by cheesy, foul-smelling nasal debris due to accumulation of keratinized material. It does not present with vascular polypoid lesions.

questions.text: Most common site of sinonasal melanoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nasal septum. Sinonasal melanoma is a rare but aggressive malignancy originating from melanocytes in the mucosa of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It accounts for less than 1% of all melanomas and 4% of all sinonasal malignancies. The most common site for sinonasal melanoma is the nasal cavity, particularly the nasal septum, followed by the lateral nasal wall. This is because the nasal septum has a higher concentration of melanocytes compared to the sinuses. Incorrect Options: (A) Frontal sinus Sinonasal melanoma rarely arises in the frontal sinus due to the low presence of melanocytes in this region. Most tumors here are squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma. (B) Maxillary sinus The maxillary sinus is the most common site for squamous cell carcinoma and adenoid cystic carcinoma, but melanoma is uncommon here. If melanoma occurs in the sinuses, it is more likely to be in the ethmoid sinus than the maxillary sinus. (C) Ethmoid sinus The ethmoid sinus is the most common site for adenocarcinoma and other malignancies, but not melanoma. Melanoma can occur here but less frequently than the nasal septum.

questions.text: Madhuri, a 35-year- old teacher, complains of a nasal quality to her voice, as well as a blocked and runny nose. She now has lost her sense of taste and smell. She also complaint of post nasal drip, she has recently been diagnosed as having asthma and has been started on oral steroids inhalers. Examination confirms the polyp-like swellings within the nose on both side. History of an adverse reaction to which drug should be enquired specifically:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aspirin. Madhuri’s symptoms, including nasal polyps, asthma, nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, and loss of taste and smell, suggest Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), also known as Samter’s Triad. AERD is characterized by: Asthma Nasal polyps Aspirin (or NSAID) hypersensitivity, leading to worsening respiratory symptoms upon exposure Patients with AERD often develop worsening nasal congestion, bronchospasm, and respiratory distress after taking aspirin or NSAIDs. This condition is due to dysregulation of arachidonic acid metabolism, causing an overproduction of leukotrienes, which lead to severe inflammation. Incorrect Options: (A) Minoxidil Minoxidil is an antihypertensive vasodilator and is not associated with nasal polyps or asthma. Its main side effects include fluid retention and hypertrichosis (excessive hair growth). (B) Cisplatin Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug, primarily causing ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuropathy. It does not trigger aspirin-induced respiratory reactions. (D) Neomycin Neomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that can cause nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity, but it is not linked to nasal polyps or asthma.

questions.text: A 14 years boy presents with nasal obstruction, proptosis (Fig),recurrent epistaxis from 3–4 years not responding to anterior nasal packing. Which artery is source of bleeding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Internal maxillary artery. A 14-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, proptosis, and recurrent epistaxis that is not responding to anterior nasal packing is highly suggestive of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA): Benign but highly vascular tumor that occurs exclusively in adolescent males. Arises from the sphenopalatine foramen in the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity. Presents with recurrent, profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and proptosis due to tumor extension into the orbit. Source of Bleeding – Internal Maxillary Artery (IMA): The Internal Maxillary Artery (IMA) is the main blood supply to JNA. It gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery, which is the major contributor to nasal mucosal vascularization. Since JNA is highly vascular, it is crucial to embolize the internal maxillary artery before surgical excision to reduce intraoperative bleeding. Incorrect Options: (B) Ascending pharyngeal artery This artery is a branch of the external carotid artery and contributes to the blood supply of the pharynx and skull base, but it is not the primary source of bleeding in JNA. (C) Facial artery The facial artery supplies the external structures of the face and contributes to the superficial vasculature of the nose but is not the primary source of bleeding in JNA. (D) Anterior ethmoidal artery The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system) and supplies the anterior nasal septum and lateral nasal wall. It is involved in epistaxis from the anterior septum (Kiesselbach’s plexus) but not in JNA, which originates deeper in the nasal cavity.
